page.title: effect on air puck - 1
page.contents:
We have an air puck (we are using an air puck so there is no friction to worry about).  It starts from rest.  Which of the following results in the puck going at a greater speed?

A: a 3 N force applied for 2 s

B: a 2 N force applied for 4 s

answer.answer_text: Force B results in a greater final speed.
answer.response: Yes.

answer.answer_text: Force A results in a greater final speed.
answer.response: No, force B imparts a larger impulse.

answer.answer_text: Both forces result in the same final speed because one is a stronger force and the other is applied for a longer time.
answer.response: No. It is true that one is stronger and the other is applied for longer. But the total effect (change in velocity) is determined by the impulse and the impulses imparted by these two forces are not equal.

answer.answer_text: We can't solve this without knowing the mass of the air puck.
answer.response: No. Without the mass of the air puck we can't predict how fast it will actually be going. But we can determine which force has the greater effect (results in a larger final speed) because we can calculate the impulses imparted by each force.

page.title: effect on air puck - 2
page.contents:
We have an air puck (we are using an air puck so there is no friction to worry about).  It starts from rest.  Which of the following results in the puck going at a greater speed?

A: an 8 N force applied for 1 s

B: a 2 N force applied for 4 s

answer.answer_text: Both forces result in the same final speed.
answer.response: Yes.

answer.answer_text: Force A results in a greater final speed.
answer.response: No, the two forces impart the same impulse.

answer.answer_text: Force B results in a greater final speed.
answer.response: No, the two forces impart the same impulse.

answer.answer_text: We can't solve this without knowing the mass of the air puck.
answer.response: No. Without the mass of the air puck we can't predict how fast it will actually be going. But we can determine which force has the greater effect (results in a larger final speed) because we can calculate the impulses imparted by each force.

page.title: Which is knocked off
page.contents:
Two identical boards hang off desks by the same amount.  A bouncy ball and a wet wad of paper are dropped onto their ends.  Both have the same mass and are going the same speed upon impact.  The ball will bounce.  The wad of paper will go “splat” (i.e. it doesn't bounce at all).

Which one, the ball or the wad, will knock its board off of the desk?

answer.response: Yes, it has the larger change in momentum, so it has the larger impulse imparted on it. So by Newton's 3rd law it also imparts the larger impulse on its board.
Think about equating impulse to change in momentum. Which has the larger change in momentum, the wad or the ball?

answer.answer_text: Geoff is trying to trick us. They will both knock their boards off.
answer.response: I frequently try to trick you (for your own good). But in this case you can take me at my word that one will knock its board off and the other won't.

answer.answer_text: Geoff is trying to trick us. Neither will knock its board off.
answer.response: I frequently try to trick you (for your own good). But in this case you can take me at my word that one will knock its board off and the other won't.

page.title: Putty ball collides with steel ball
page.contents:
A 1.0 kg Silly PuttyTM ball moving 2.0 m/s to the right collides head on
with a 2.0 kg steel ball moving to the left at 1.0 m/s. Which ball has more
momentum?

answer.answer_text: The magnitudes of their momenta are equal.
answer.response: Yes, they both have momenta of 2 kg m/s.
No, magnitude of momentum is just mv. What they are made of is irrelevant. They both have momenta of 2 kg m/s.
No, magnitude of momentum is just mv. What they are made of is irrelevant. They both have momenta of 2 kg m/s.
No, magnitude of momentum is just mv. They both have momenta of 2 kg m/s.

page.title: momentum conservation of bouncing ball
page.contents: A ball is dropped and bounces off of the floor. Its speed immediately before the bounce is the same as its speed immediately after the bounce. If the system that we consider is only the ball, is the momentum of the system conserved?

answer.answer_text: No, because the ball has reversed the direction of its velocity.
answer.response: Yes. Momentum is a vector so direction matters.

answer.answer_text: Yes, because if the speed is the same before and after then so is the momentum.
answer.response: No. Momentum is a vector. Direction matters when you are deciding whether it has changed or not.

answer.answer_text: We need to know the mass and velocity of the ball to answer this.
answer.response: No, we don't. If you just draw the momentum vectors before and after the collision for the ball you will see that the momentum has changed.

answer.answer_text: The momentum is only partly conserved because the Earth is not moving.
answer.response: Momentum is either conserved or it isn't. There is no such thing as being "partly conserved".

page.title: Brick into bin
page.contents:
The figure shows a brick being thrown into a bin at a construction site.  Before the brick lands in the bin, the brick is moving in the direction shown.  After the brick lands in the bin, the brick and the bin are moving together with a velocity to the right as shown.

Consider the system to be the brick and the bin.  Is the momentum of the system conserved in the collision?

answer.response: Yes. The vertical component is not conserved. However, the horizontal component is conserved and could by used to find how fast the brick and bin move after the collision.

No, the momentum of the system must be right and down before the collision, but it must be to the right after the collision. So the direction of the momentum has changed and the momentum has not been conserved.

answer.answer_text: We need to know the masses of both objects and the velocity of the brick before the collision.
answer.response: No we don't. The directions of the velocities make it clear that the direction of the momentum vector must have changed during the collision.

page.title: All reflections
page.contents:
This is only here so that if the Lesson navigation failed and you couldn't access one of the Reflective Writing pages you can view their content here.  Most of the time there should be no need for you to visit this page.

----------After Lecture 2-----------

Take out a piece of paper.  Write "PHYS 1101 - Response to Unit 8 Video Lectures" across the top of the paper and put your name in an upper corner of the page.  Write a big heading saying "Lectures 1-2".  

Under that answer these questions:

1. Point of confusion: Identify something that confused you during the lecture.  If you are still confused by it then try to explain, in reasonable detail, exactly why you are confused.  If you are no longer confused then explain how you resolved your confusion (i.e. what realizations led you to no longer being confused).  Be as specific as you can about the nature of your confusion.  It is not acceptable to simply say that you were not confused by anything.  If you think you were not confused by anything then you are not thinking about the material carefully enough.

2. Something you have seen before: Identify something from any of the videos on this unit that you have seen before.  If it was presented differently from how you have seen it previously then briefly describe the difference.  It is not acceptable to say that nothing in the videos was something you have seen before.  All knowledge is built on earlier knowledge and there must be something in these videos that was at least somewhat familiar.

3. Explain, in your own words, why the methods that we learned in earlier units of the course are not very useful tor analyzing collisions.

You will add more to this sheet after some of the other lectures in this unit.

------------After Lecture 4-----------

You should already have a sheet of paper that you wrote some things on after watching Lecture 2.  If you don't already have that (perhaps because you are watching the videos out of sequence) then go back to Lecture 2, watch it, answer the questions and then start your writing.  Then come back to this page.

Under what you wrote for Lecture 2 write a heading saying "End of Lectures".  

Under that heading answer the following questions:

1. Point of confusion: Identify something that confused you during the lecture.  If you are still confused by it then try to explain, in reasonable detail, exactly why you are confused.  If you are no longer confused then explain how you resolved your confusion (i.e. what realizations led you to no longer being confused).  Be as specific as you can about the nature of your confusion.  It is not acceptable to simply say that you were not confused by anything.  If you think you were not confused by anything then you are not thinking about the material carefully enough.

2. Question beyond the lecture: Ask a question that goes beyond what was covered in the lectures.  This could be a question about a topic that you think might be related to the lectures, or something that you suspect might be a more advanced topic that the material in these lectures might eventually lead to.  Or it might be something that I mentioned briefly, but didn't go into detail on.  Make your question as specific as you can.

3. In the car collision in Lecture 3 I made an argument for why we can probably approximate friction as negligible, even though the friction forces acting on the cars are not what you would normally think of as "small".  My argument was a bit long and maybe difficult to follow.  Summarize, more briefly, why we could often neglect friction with the road when we are analyzing  a  collision between cars.

You will scan this sheet, along with an addition to your cheat sheet, and submit it on moodle under the Written Response for this lesson.

answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: force in collision of unequal mass balls
page.contents: A steel ball of mass 3.0 kg moving at 1.0 m/s to the right collides with another steel ball of mass 1.0 kg moving at 2.0 m/s to the left. Which ball exerts the larger magnitude of force on the other ball over the course of the collision?

answer.answer_text: They each exert the same magnitude of force on the other.
answer.response: Yes, that's what Newton's 3rd Law says.

answer.answer_text: The 3.0 kg ball because it is more massive.
answer.response: No. What does Newton's 3rd Law say?

answer.answer_text: The 1.0 kg ball because it is going faster.
answer.response: No. What does Newton's 3rd Law say?
No. There is a law which tells us the answer to this.

page.contents: End of cluster

In the car collision in Lecture 3 I made an argument for why we can probably approximate friction as negligible, even though the friction forces acting on the cars are not what you would normally think of as "small".  My argument was a bit long and maybe difficult to follow.  Summarize, more briefly, why we could often neglect friction with the road when we are analyzing  a  collision between cars.

page.title: force in steel ball/putty ball collision
page.contents: A steel ball of mass 2.0 kg moving at 1.0 m/s to the right collides with a silly putty ball of mass 2.0 kg moving at 1.0 m/s to the left. Which ball exerts the larger magnitude of force on the other during the collision?

answer.answer_text: They each exert the same magnitude of force.
answer.response: Yes, that's what Newton's 3rd Law says.
What does Newton's 3rd Law tell us?
What does Newton's 3rd Law tell us?
No, there is a law which tells us the answer to this one.

page.title: impulse imparted upon putty ball vs. steel ball
page.contents: A 1.0 kg putty ball, moving at 10 m/s, hits a wall and sticks to it. A 1.0 kg steel ball, also moving at 10 m/s, hits the wall and bounces off with a speed after the collision of nearly 10 m/s. Which ball should you expect to impart a greater impulse on the wall during the collision and why?

answer.response: Yes. The vector subtraction of momentums tells us that the steel ball had a greater impulse imparted upon it.

answer.answer_text: They both were moving at the same speed and had the same mass so they will have imparted equal impulses.
answer.response: Impulse

answer.answer_text: The impulse on the steel ball is zero (final speed = initial speed). So the putty ball must have imparted a larger impulse.
answer.response: Remember that momentum and impulse are both vectors. The speeds of the steel ball before and after the collision with the wall may be the same, but the velocities are not. So the impulse on the steel ball is not zero.

answer.answer_text: The putty ball will have imparted a greater impulse because its collision with the wall is completely elastic.
answer.response: Well, we haven't discussed the idea of elastic vs. inelastic collisions yet. So it would have been unfair of me to give a question which required you to know about them. But in any case this is incorrect. The collision of the putty ball with the wall is completely *inelastic*.

page.title: which has more momentum - 1
page.contents: A 1.0 kg aluminum ball is moving to the right at 2.0 m/s. A 3.0 kg brass ball is moving to the left at 1.0 m/s. Which ball has a greater magnitude of momentum?

answer.response: Yes, the aluminum ball has a momentum component of 2 kg m/s and the brass one has a momentum component of 3 kg m/s.
Magnitude of momentum is just mv. So the aluminum ball has a momentum of 2 kg m/s and the brass one has a momentum of 3 kg m/s.
Magnitude of momentum is just mv. So the aluminum ball has a momentum of 2 kg m/s and the brass one has a momentum of 3 kg m/s.
Magnitude of momentum is just mv. So the aluminum ball has a momentum of 2 kg m/s and the brass one has a momentum of 3 kg m/s.
